text: <@U013206C8RE> has joined the channel

Evening, I was recently fortunate enough to have the TPD GPS Switched on for me by my account manager.
A number of fellow users have proclaimed how useful this is, but hand on heart, I haven’t been able to capitalise on it. (Either as a standalone strategy or to enhance existing strategies)
So for the time being, I have switched back to my long term non TPD profitable stuff.
I don't how many licences Betfair have allocated in total but I expect that a number of those granted access will be on here, so a good place to ask.
So how have you found it? Appreciate any thoughts, reflections please.
Either-way I will be looking at this again over the holidays, just looking for a gauge rather than the secret sauce thanks :grinning:

elements.text:
Evening, I was recently fortunate enough to have the TPD GPS Switched on for me by my account manager.
A number of fellow users have proclaimed how useful this is, but hand on heart, I haven’t been able to capitalise on it. (Either as a standalone strategy or to enhance existing strategies)
So for the time being, I have switched back to my long term non TPD profitable stuff.
I don't how many licences Betfair have allocated in total but I expect that a number of those granted access will be on here, so a good place to ask.
So how have you found it? Appreciate any thoughts, reflections please.
Either-way I will be looking at this again over the holidays, just looking for a gauge rather than the secret sauce thanks

text: Also had to shelve it in favour of more established strategies

elements.text: Also had to shelve it in favour of more established strategies

text: No real historic data is a big barrier to entry that protects the guys who have had it from day one

elements.text: No real historic data is a big barrier to entry that protects the guys who have had it from day one

user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: - I thought you were a tennis guy?

text: Sure but everyone makes out that the TPD feed is a license to print money so why not give it a whirl?

elements.text: Sure but everyone makes out that the TPD feed is a license to print money so why not give it a whirl?

text: I thought it would be too time consuming. And as you said, a lack of historic data is a big barrier to entry.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I thought it would be too time consuming. And as you said, a lack of historic data is a big barrier to entry.

text: I can't even get an in-running strategy to work without TPD. So adding TPD would just complicate matters anyway

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I can't even get an in-running strategy to work without TPD. So adding TPD would just complicate matters anyway

text: An advantage of being in a syndicate is different people can work on different things

elements.text: An advantage of being in a syndicate is different people can work on different things

text: I'm just a solo part-timer. How did you get started as a syndicate?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I'm just a solo part-timer. How did you get started as a syndicate?

text: Tennis is my bread and butter but I’ve worked on strategies for football, horse racing, NASCAR and golf over the years

elements.text: Tennis is my bread and butter but I’ve worked on strategies for football, horse racing, NASCAR and golf over the years

text: The first syndicate I was part of I just joined as an employee

elements.text: The first syndicate I was part of I just joined as an employee

text: Does it vary a lot to more conventional jobs? I've had interviews with one or two syndicates in the past, but nothing's materialised before a more normal company gave me an offer. So I'm still working for a normal company.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Does it vary a lot to more conventional jobs? I've had interviews with one or two syndicates in the past, but nothing's materialised before a more normal company gave me an offer. So I'm still working for a normal company.

text: There are syndicates, and then there are organisations/businesses. I worked mainly for the latter. First client had 5 people full-time when I started, and over 20 when I left. Second client had around 20 people full-time when I started, and morphed into an organisation with over 100. For those type of places, these jobs are just normal jobs (and paid accordingly). I also worked for a smaller syndicate which included a form of profit-share

elements.text: There are syndicates, and then there are organisations/businesses. I worked mainly for the latter. First client had 5 people full-time when I started, and over 20 when I left. Second client had around 20 people full-time when I started, and morphed into an organisation with over 100. For those type of places, these jobs are just normal jobs (and paid accordingly). I also worked for a smaller syndicate which included a form of profit-share

text: Although you get out of there with quite some knowledge, I see...

elements.text: Although you get out of there with quite some knowledge, I see...

text: <@U01C12ZEADQ> - just like any other job. If you work in the same industry for 10 years and soak up as much knowledge as you can about everything, you become an expert :wink:

elements.text: - just like any other job. If you work in the same industry for 10 years and soak up as much knowledge as you can about everything, you become an expert

text: No - I have moved from horse racing (previous work) to tennis

text: My knowledge of horse racing, while fairly good, is not good enough (I reckon) to start from scratch in terms of modelling

elements.text: My knowledge of horse racing, while fairly good, is not good enough (I reckon) to start from scratch in terms of modelling

text: My view, and this is my view only, is that I find it hard to model if I am not a real expert in the field. I know that others can overcome this, but I would rather work on "solid ground" :wink:

elements.text: My view, and this is my view only, is that I find it hard to model if I am not a real expert in the field. I know that others can overcome this, but I would rather work on "solid ground"

text: It's not a coincidence that most of the successful TPD players were established IR horses players before it came along. To me using TPD does feel like printing money, but then I was already doing well on those markets before it existed. Having been betting blind on HR markets for years suddenly having a notion of what's actually happening in the race was miraculous. I wasn't troubled by lack of data because I could use my existing market analysis techniques to make sure I wasn't doing anything ludicrous and I already had a good idea of how to pitch the betting in terms of staking, pricing and so on. Absent all of that I can see it being much harder and I've heard similar experiences to <@UQL0QDEKA> from a few people.

elements.text: It's not a coincidence that most of the successful TPD players were established IR horses players before it came along.
